title: Trust in God Amid Persecution
shortSummary: Psalm 56 is a heartfelt prayer of David during a time of great distress when he was captured by the Philistines in Gath. The psalm expresses deep trust in God’s protection and deliverance despite overwhelming enemies and fear, highlighting the believer’s confidence in God’s faithfulness.
timeline: c. 1000 BC - Reign of King David, during his flight from Saul and captivity by the Philistines

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: The author of the psalm, a shepherd, warrior, and future king of Israel, who writes this lament while imprisoned by the Philistines.

keyCharacters.name: Philistines
keyCharacters.description: The enemies who captured David in Gath, representing external threats and persecution.

definitions.definition: A term of uncertain meaning used in the titles of some psalms, possibly indicating a golden or precious poem.
Likely a musical or liturgical term related to the psalm’s performance, possibly meaning 'the silent dove' or a specific melody.
A metaphorical container used here to signify God’s careful preservation and remembrance of the psalmist’s tears and sufferings.
Sacred promises made to God, often in response to deliverance or answered prayer.

outline.heading: David’s Plea for Mercy and Description of His Persecution
outline.description: David begins by asking God for mercy as he faces daily oppression from many enemies who seek to destroy him.

outline.heading: Expression of Trust in God Despite Fear
outline.description: David acknowledges his fear but declares his trust in God’s word and protection, refusing to fear what man can do.

outline.heading: Enemies’ Schemes and David’s Confidence in God’s Justice
outline.description: The psalmist describes the deceit and plotting of his enemies and calls on God to bring judgment upon them in His anger.

outline.heading: God’s Care and Assurance of Deliverance
outline.description: David affirms that God records his sufferings and tears and promises that when he calls, God will cause his enemies to retreat.

outline.heading: Renewed Praise and Commitment to Trust
outline.description: David repeats his commitment to praise God’s word and trust Him fully, acknowledging God’s past deliverance and pledging continued worship.

application: In times of fear and oppression, place your full trust in God’s promises rather than in human strength or circumstances.
Remember to bring your fears and tears to God in prayer, knowing He cares deeply and records your sufferings.
Commit to praising God’s word continually, especially when facing trials, as a means of strengthening faith and courage.
Make and keep vows of thanksgiving to God when He delivers you, demonstrating gratitude and faithfulness.

keyVerses.text: What time I am afraid, I will trust in thee.
keyVerses.significance: This verse encapsulates the psalmist’s faith response to fear, encouraging believers to trust God even in fearful circumstances.

keyVerses.text: Thou tellest my wanderings: put thou my tears into thy bottle: are they not in thy book?
keyVerses.significance: It highlights God’s intimate knowledge and care for the believer’s suffering, assuring that no pain is unnoticed.

keyVerses.text: In God have I put my trust: I will not be afraid what man can do unto me.
keyVerses.significance: This verse boldly declares the believer’s confidence in God’s protection over human threats.

keyVerses.text: For thou hast delivered my soul from death: wilt not thou deliver my feet from falling, that I may walk before God in the light of the living?
keyVerses.significance: It expresses gratitude for past deliverance and a prayer for continued guidance to live faithfully before God.
